questions.text: Which of the following is not a requirement for the activity of DNA polymerase during DNA replication?

options.label: A
options.text: A primer with a free 3′-OH group

options.label: D
options.text: A divalent cation cofactor, typically Mg²⁺

questions.text: A scientist observes the process of DNA replication in a human stem cell. He takes a sample of double-stranded DNA from the cell and studies it separately. He finds that the total amount of adenine in the sample is 24%. From the given information, what percentage of cytosine is present in the sample?
What is the wavelength at which nucleic acids show maximum absorbance of UV light?
questions.explanation:
Molecule Maximum Absorbance (nm) Reason
DNA/RNA 260 nm Nitrogenous bases (purines & pyrimidines)
Proteins 280 nm (Option B ruled out) Aromatic amino acids (tryptophan & tyrosine)
NADH/NADPH  340 nm (Option D ruled out) Reduced nicotinamide ring
Hemoglobin 400 nm (Option C ruled out) Heme group

questions.text: What sequence is repeated in human telomeres?
questions.explanation:
Feature Description
Sequence 5'-TTAGGG-3' repeat
Function Protects chromosome ends from degradation and fusion
Telomerase Activity Adds repeats using an RNA template
Shortening Effect Telomeres shorten with each cell division due to incomplete lagging strand synthesis
Associated Diseases Premature telomere shortening is linked to aging and diseases like dyskeratosis congenita and aplastic anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by a defective NER mechanism?
What is the role of UvrABC exinuclease in nucleotide excision repair (NER)?

options.label: A
options.text: It fills in the gap with new nucleotides

options.label: B
options.text: It recognizes and excises damaged DNA segments.

options.label: C
options.text: It seals the DNA strand after repair.

options.label: D
options.text: It unwinds the DNA double helix.

questions.correct_answer: B. It recognizes and excises damaged DNA segments.

questions.text: Mismatch repair defects are mostly associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Syndrome Genetic Defect Cancer Risk
HNPCC (Lynch Syndrome) MMR gene mutations (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2) Colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, gastric cancers
FAP (Familial Adenomatous Polyposis) (Option B ruled out) APC gene mutation Multiple colorectal adenomas, colon cancer
Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (Option C ruled out) TP53 mutation Breast, brain, sarcomas, leukemias
Retinoblastoma (Option D ruled out) RB1 gene mutation Retinoblastoma, osteosarcoma

questions.text: Why are methylases important in the mismatch repair mechanism in prokaryotes like E. coli?

options.label: A
options.text: They add methyl groups to the newly synthesized DNA strand, marking it for repair.

options.label: B
options.text: They methylate the parental DNA strand, allowing the Mut proteins to distinguish it from the daughter strand.

options.label: C
options.text: They remove mismatched bases from the DNA strand.

options.label: D
options.text: They act as exonucleases during the repair process.

questions.correct_answer: B. They methylate the parental DNA strand, allowing the Mut proteins to distinguish it from the daughter strand.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes helps remove the defective base during base excision repair (BER)?
A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent respiratory infections and poor growth despite a normal diet. Genetic testing reveals Cystic fibrosis. What type of mutation causes cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Phenotypic heterogeneity

(Option A ruled out)

Pleiotropy

(Option B ruled out)

Allelic heterogeneity

(Option C)

Variability in the phenotype that is caused by mutations in the same gene
  • Disorders where multiple, seemingly unrelated organ systems are affected.
  • A single gene is responsible for several distinct and seemingly unrelated phenotypic effects

Different mutations (changes) in a single gene cause the same disease or condition

Example:

Loss-of-function mutations in the RET gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase, leads to inherited failure of development of colonic ganglia, leading to defective colonic motility and severe chronic constipation (Hirschsprung disease)

Example:

The allele causing neurofibromatosis type 1 can produce abnormalities of skin pigmentation, neurofibromas of the peripheral nerves, short stature, macrocephaly, skeletal abnormalities, and fits

Example:

Cystic fibrosis is caused by having one of many different mutations in the CFTR gene.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of DNA polymerase δ (Pol δ) in eukaryotic cells?

options.label: A
options.text: It synthesizes RNA primers necessary for DNA replication.

options.label: B
options.text: It is responsible for leading-strand DNA synthesis.

options.label: C
options.text: It requires a primer and provides proofreading during lagging-strand synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: It directly repairs damaged DNA by filling in gaps.

questions.correct_answer: C. It requires a primer and provides proofreading during lagging-strand synthesis.
questions.explanation:
DNA Polymerase Function
Pol α Synthesizes RNA primers and initiates DNA synthesis
Pol δ Lagging-strand synthesis, proofreading, and high-fidelity replication
Pol ε Leading-strand synthesis and proofreading
Pol β Involved in base excision repair (BER)
Pol γ Replicates mitochondrial DNA

questions.text: Which of the following statements about telomeres and telomerase is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomeres prevent chromosome ends from degrading but do not shorten during cell division.

options.label: B
options.text: Telomerase adds repetitive DNA sequences to the 5′ end of chromosomes

options.label: C
options.text: Telomeres are composed of repetitive sequences that help prevent chromosome fusion.

options.label: D
options.text: The shortening of telomeres occurs due to the continuous synthesis of the lagging strand.

questions.correct_answer: C. Telomeres are composed of repetitive sequences that help prevent chromosome fusion.
questions.explanation:
Feature Description
Telomere Composition Repetitive TTAGGG sequences in humans
Function Protect chromosome ends from degradation and fusion
Shortening Mechanism Due to incomplete lagging strand synthesis in DNA replication
Role of Telomerase Extends the 3′ end of DNA using an RNA template to compensate for shortening
Cell Types with Active Telomerase Germ cells, stem cells, and cancer cells

Aspect

Description

Telomeres

Protective structures at chromosome ends; repetitive DNA (5′-TTAGGG-3′)

Telomere Shortening

Occurs during replication; lagging strand lacks template for primer synthesis, leading to progressive shortening

Telomerase

RNA-dependent DNA polymerase; adds TTAGGG repeats using its RNA template

questions.text: Which of the following statements about DNA polymerases in E. coli is true?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA Polymerase I is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis at the replication fork.

options.label: B
options.text: DNA Polymerase II is primarily responsible for gap filling following DNA replication

options.label: C
options.text: DNA Polymerase III has the highest rate of chain elongation and is involved in both leading and lagging strand synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: All three DNA polymerases perform identical functions in DNA synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: C. DNA Polymerase III has the highest rate of chain elongation and is involved in both leading and lagging strand synthesis.
questions.explanation:
DNA Polymerase

Main Function

Additional Notes

DNA Polymerase I

Proofreading, DNA repair, gap filling

Involved in recombination

DNA Polymerase II

Proofreading, DNA repair

Similar function to pol I

DNA Polymerase III

Main enzyme for DNA synthesis

Highest processivity; synthesizes leading and lagging strands; associates with sliding clamp β subunits

questions.text: Which of the following is not a requirement for DNA replication in eukaryotes?
questions.explanation:
Component Function
Origin of Replication (ori) (Option A ruled out) Specific DNA sequences where replication starts
DNA Helicase (Option B ruled out) Unwinds the DNA double helix
Single-Strand Binding Proteins (SSBPs) Stabilize unwound DNA strands
Primase (RNA polymerase type) Synthesizes short RNA primers
DNA Polymerase α, δ, and ε Synthesizes new DNA strands
Sliding Clamp (PCNA) Enhances DNA polymerase processivity
Topoisomerase Relieves supercoiling ahead of the replication fork
DNA Ligase Seals Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand

Step

Description

1. Identification of Ori

Specific DNA sequence where replication begins.

2. Unwinding of DNA

DNA helicase unwinds dsDNA, and SSBs stabilize ssDNA.

3. Replication Fork Formation

Fork consists of DNA helicase, SSBs, primase, and DNA polymerase; primase synthesizes RNA primer.

4. DNA Synthesis Initiation/Elongation

DNA polymerase extends RNA primer by adding deoxynucleotides.

5. Replication Bubbles/Ligation

Bidirectional replication creates bubbles; Okazaki fragments are joined by DNA ligase.

6. Chromatin Reconstitution

Newly replicated DNA is assembled into nucleosomes.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders are not caused due to defect in the Non homologous End Joining?

A 45 y/o woman presents with visual disturbances, including gradual vision loss and difficulty seeing in low light, along with muscle weakness and fatigue. She has a history of early-onset cardiac conduction issues and worsening symptoms over the years. Her family history shows similar symptoms in her mother. What genetic condition best explains her symptoms?

options.label: B
options.text: Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers (MERRF)

options.label: C
options.text: Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes (MELAS)

questions.explanation:
Syndrome Genetic Defect Key Clinical Features
Leber’s Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (LHON) mtDNA mutations in ND1, ND4, ND6 (Complex I subunits) Painless, progressive vision loss, optic atrophy, cardiac conduction defects, maternal inheritance

Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers (MERRF)

(Option B ruled out)

 mtDNA mutations in MT-TK (tRNA-Lys gene) Myoclonic epilepsy, muscle weakness, ataxia, hearing loss, ragged red fibers on muscle biopsy

Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like Episodes (MELAS)

(Option C ruled out)

 mtDNA mutations in MT-TL1 (tRNA-Leu gene) Stroke-like episodes, lactic acidosis, seizures, progressive dementia, diabetes, muscle weakness

Leigh’s Syndrome

(Option D ruled out)

 mtDNA or nuclear DNA mutations (Complex I or IV defects, NDUFS genes) Neurodegeneration in infancy, hypotonia, brainstem dysfunction, ataxia, respiratory failure
Kearns-Sayre Syndrome (KSS) Large-scale mtDNA deletions Progressive external ophthalmoplegia, pigmentary retinopathy, cardiac conduction defects, muscle weakness

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA)?

options.label: B
options.text: It has very few non-coding regions and a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: It uses the standard genetic code, including AGA and AGG as codons for arginine (Arg).

options.label: D
options.text: It is composed of linear strands and encodes for all 67 subunits of the respiratory chain.

questions.correct_answer: B. It has very few non-coding regions and a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Structure

Circular, double-stranded; composed of heavy (H) and light (L) chains. (Option A ruled out)

Length

16,569 base pairs (bp).

Protein-Encoding Subunits

 Most respiratory chain proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and imported into mitochondria (Option D ruled out)

Ribosomal RNAs

Encodes 16S (large) and 12S (small) mitochondrial rRNAs.

tRNAs

Encodes 22 mitochondrial tRNA molecules.

Genetic Code Differences

UGA typically a stop codon is read as tryptophan (Trp)

AGA and AGG: normally arginine (Arg) codons are read as stop codons (Option C ruled out)

Untranslated Sequences

Very few non-coding regions.

Mutation Rate

5-10 times higher than nuclear DNA.

Evolutionary Studies

Comparisons of mtDNA sequences provide insights into the evolutionary history of primates and other species.

questions.text: Which histone is least tightly bound to chromatin and can be easily removed with a salt solution?
questions.explanation:
Histone Type Function Binding to DNA
H1 (Linker Histone) Stabilizes nucleosomes, promotes chromatin compaction Least tightly bound, removable with salt solutions
H2A, H2B (Core Histones) (Option A ruled out) Form histone octamer, aid in nucleosome structure Tightly bound
H3, H4 (Core Histones) (Options C & D ruled out) Critical for nucleosome stability and gene regulation Tightly bound

questions.text: Which of the following factors can cause the denaturation of DNA? a) Increasing temperature b) Increasing salt concentration c) Decreasing temperature d) DNA with a high A-T base composition e) DNA with a high G-C base composition f) Adding Urea g) Adding Formamide h) Decreasing salt concentration
questions.correct_answer: C. a, d, f, g, h

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the different types of DNA is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: B-DNA has a left-handed helix and a full turn with 12 bases.

options.label: B
options.text: A-DNA forms during dehydration and has grooves of the same dimensions.

options.label: C
options.text: Z-DNA forms under normal physiological conditions and has a right-handed helix

options.label: D
options.text: A-DNA is the predominant form found in physiological conditions and has 11 bases per full turn.

questions.correct_answer: B. A-DNA forms during dehydration and has grooves of the same dimensions.
questions.explanation:
Type of DNA Helical Direction Base Pairs per Turn Grooves Conditions
B-DNA Right-handed 10.5 Major groove is wide and deep, minor groove is narrow Physiological conditions
A-DNA Right-handed 11 Grooves are of nearly equal dimensions Forms during dehydration
Z-DNA Left-handed 12 Major groove is shallow, minor groove is deep Forms under high salt or supercoiling

questions.text: In the analogy of the DNA double helix to a spiral staircase, what do the "handrails" and "steps" represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Handrails are nitrogenous bases; steps are phosphodiester bonds

options.label: B
options.text: Handrails are nitrogenous bases; steps are the sugar-phosphate backbone

options.label: C
options.text: Handrails are the sugar-phosphate backbone; steps are nitrogenous bases

options.label: D
options.text: Handrails are hydrogen bonds; steps are deoxyribose sugars

questions.correct_answer: C. Handrails are the sugar-phosphate backbone; steps are nitrogenous bases

questions.text: In the structure of nucleotides, where does the esterification of the phosphate group typically occur?

options.label: A
options.text: On the 1' carbon of the pentose sugar

options.label: B
options.text: On the 2' hydroxyl group of the pentose sugar

options.label: C
options.text: On the 5' or 3' hydroxyl group of the pentose sugar

options.label: D
options.text: On the N1 position of the nitrogenous base

questions.correct_answer: C. On the 5' or 3' hydroxyl group of the pentose sugar

questions.text: What is the primary role of inosine monophosphate (IMP) in cellular metabolism?

options.label: A
options.text: Directly involved in energy transfer like ATP

options.label: B
options.text: Acts as a precursor for both adenosine monophosphate (AMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP)

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits the de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides

options.label: D
options.text: Serves as an end product of the salvage pathway for purine nucleotides

questions.correct_answer: B. Acts as a precursor for both adenosine monophosphate (AMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP)

questions.text: What type of bond forms between a nitrogenous base and a pentose sugar in a nucleoside?
Which of the following is a pyrimidine base found in nucleic acids?
Which of the following is not caused by a defect of ds DNA repair?
questions.explanation:
Disorder Defective Repair Mechanism
Ataxia telangiectasia Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ)
Bloom’s syndrome (Option D ruled out) Homologous DNA Repair (HDR)
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) (Option C ruled out) Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ)
Fanconi’s anemia (Option B ruled out) Fanconi Anemia Repair Pathway (Interacts with HDR)
HBOC (Human Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome) Homologous DNA Repair (HDR) (BRCA1/BRCA2 mutation)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Homologous DNA Repair (HR) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: HR is active during G0/G1 phases of the cell cycle.

options.label: B
options.text: HR is an error-prone process compared to nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ).

options.label: C
options.text: HR uses a homologous DNA template for repair, making it highly accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: Defects in HR-related proteins decrease Ovarian and breast cancers

questions.correct_answer: C. HR uses a homologous DNA template for repair, making it highly accurate.
